description: From Middle English inblowen, from Old English inblāwan (“to inspire, breathe upon, inflate, puff up”), equivalent to in- +‎ blow.

entries.meaning: The act or process of blowing in or into; inflation.
examples: During the full gasification stage, after piercing has been effected, the enlargement of the cracks requires a progressively increasing inblow.

verbs.description: inblow (third-person singular simple present inblows, present participle inblowing, simple past inblew, past participle inblown)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To blow into; puff up; inflate.

examples: Then the spiritual and sensory faculties follow the creation of this partial spirit that is inblown by way of tawḥīd, for He says, I blew [15:29]. As for the spirit of Jesus, it is inblown through bringing together and manyness, for within him are the faculties ...
